questions.text: Which of the following muscles is responsible for ptosis in horner's syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Muller's Muscle Ptosis in Horner syndrome is due to paralysis of Muller’s muscle.

Highyeild:

HORNER SYNDROME Horner’s syndrome occurs due to oculosympathetic paresis. It is characterized by Ptosis Miosis Anhidrosis Enophthalmos Loss of ciliospinal reflex Heterochromia iridis

questions.text: An 11-years-old presented with the following growth in the eye as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Limbal dermoid Above image shows limbal Dermoid.

Highyeild:

DERMOIDS These are common congenital tumours which usually occur at the limbus. They appear as solid white masses, firmly fixed to the cornea. Dermoid consists of collagenous connective tissue, sebaceous glands and hair, lined by epidermoid epithelium. Treatment is simple excision. Limbal dermoid

questions.text: Patient undergoes lens implantation following which there's worsening of vision after 1 year. Slit lamp examination finding is shown in the image below. Identify the complication:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Posterior subcapsular cataract Above image shows vacuolated clusters seen behind IOL is suggestive of Elschnig pearls which is a type of Posterior subcapsular cataract.

Highyeild:

Aftercataract It is also known as secondary Cataract is the most common postoperative complication. It is the opacity which persists or develops after extracapsular lens extraction. Clinical types. After-cataract may present as: Tenures posterior capsule opacification (PCO). Dense membranous after cataract. Soemmering's ring which refers to a thick ring of after cataract formed behind the iris, enclosed between the two layers of capsule. Elschnig's pearls in which the vacuolated subcapsular epithelial cells are clustered like soap bubbles along the posterior capsule . Types of after-cataract: A, Dense membranous. B. Spemmering's ring: C. Elschnig's pearls Treatment: Thin membranous after cataract, thickened posterior capsule and Elschnig's pearls involving the central part of the posterior capsule are best treated by YAG-laser capsulotomy.

Solution:

Blind spot enlargement Above image shows blind spot enlargement. Most common cause is idiopathic intracranial hypertension.

Highyeild:

VISUAL FIELD DEFECTS IN PRIMARY OPEN ANGLE GLAUCOMA Field defects in POAG: A. Baring of blind spot: Superior paracentral scotoma: C. Seidel's scotoma; D. Bjerrum's scotoma; E. Double arcuate scotoma and Roenne's central nasal step

questions.text: A patient undergoes worth's four-dot test. The results are as shown in the image below. Identify the condition:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Right suppression Given image with 3 green dots likely suggests that the patient is suffering from right suppression.

Highyeild:

Worth's four-dot test. For this test, patient wears goggles with red lens in front of the right and green lens in front of the left eye and views a box with four lights-one red, two green and one white. Results are interpreted as below: In normal binocular single vision, the patient sees all the four lights in the absence of manifest squint. ln abnormal retinal correspondence (ARC), patient sees four lights even in the presence of a manifest squint. ln left suppression, the patient sees only two red lights. In right suppression, the patient sees only three green lights. In alternating suppression, the patient sees three green lights and two red lights, alternately. In diplopia, the patient sees five lights (2 red and 3 green).

questions.text: A 20-year-old presented with gradual loss of vision at night and a fundoscopy image is shown. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Retinitis Pigmentosa Fundus image shown above shows a pale waxy disc, attenuated arteries and bony spicules along with gradual loss of vision suggesting it to be a case of retinitis Pigmentosa.

Highyeild:

RETINITIS PIGMENTOSA Retinitis pigmentosa, primary pigmentary retinal dystrophy is a hereditary disorder predominantly affecting the photoreceptor(rods more than the cones). Visual Symptoms: Night blindness- It is the characteristic and earliest feature. Dark adaptation. Tubular vision, i.e. loss of peripheral vision with preservation of central vision occurs in advanced cases. Central vision is also lost ultimately after many years. Fundus changes: Retinal pigmentary changes- These are typically perivascular (around veins) and jet black spots resembling bone corpuscles in shape. Fundus picture of retinitis pigmentosa with consecutive optic atrophy Thinning and atrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) is seen in mid and far peripheral retina with relative sparing of RPE at the macula. Optic disc becomes pale and waxy in later stages and ultimately consecutive optic atrophy occurs Visual Field changes Annular or ring-shaped scotoma is a typical feature which corresponds to the degenerated equatorial zone of retina. Field changes in reties pigmentosa Electrophysiological changes Electroretinogram (ERG) is initially subnormal (scotopic affected before photopic; b-wave affected before a wave) and eventually extinguished. Electro-oculogram {EOG) is subnormal with an absence of light peak.

questions.text: A 2-month-old girl child was brought to the hospital by her parents with the following presentation. What is the appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Immediate surgery Above patient with leukocoria in the left eye is likely indicative of Congenital infantile cataract. Immediate surgery is the most appropriate management.

Highyeild:

Indications and timing of paediatric cataract surgery: Partial cataracts and small central cataracts which are visually insignificant can safely be ignored and observed or may need non-surgical treatment with pupillary dilatation. Bilateral dense cataracts should be removed early within 6 weeks of birth ) to prevent stimulus deprivation amblyopia. Second eye should be operated within a few days of the first eye. Unilateral dense cataract should preferably be removed as early as possible (within days) after birth with optical correction in the first few weeks. However, it must be borne in mind that visual prognosis in most of the unilateral cases is very poor even after timely operation, because correction of aphakia and prevention of amblyopia in infants is an uphill task.

questions.text: A patient wearing contact lenses develops pain in the orbital region. He has had a very casual attitude towards cleaning his contact lenses. He presented with corneal ulcer and keratitis. Scrapings showed an organism with a spine-like pseudopodia. Which organism is the likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acanthamoeba Above clinical history of orbital pain in a contact lens wearer and demonstration of corneal ulcer and keratitis with Scrapings showing an organism with a spine-like pseudopodia, is suggestive of Acanthamoeba keratitis. Organism responsible for it is

Highyeild:

ACANTHAMOEBA KERATITIS Symptoms: These vary from asymptomatic to foreign body sensation, mild pain to severe pain (out of proportion to the degree of inflammation), watering, photophobia, blepharospasm and blurred vision. Signs: Acanthamoeba keratitis evolves over several months as a gradual worsening keratitis with periods of temporary remission. Epithelial lesions occur initially and Include Epithelial roughening and irregularities, often mistaken for punctate epitheliopathy. Epithelial ridges, i.e. raised epithelial lines, initially, typical reticular pattern in seen due to radial Kerato neuritis. Radial kerato neuritis, reported in 50% cases, seems to be a pathognomonic early sign. It is thought to be the cause of severe pain disproportionate to inflammation. Pseudo dendrites formation occurs and at this stage, it is commonly mistaken for herpes simplex keratitis. Epithelial and subepithelial curvilinear opacities (usually fine). Ring infiltrates, central or paracentral, with overlying epithelial defects and underlying keratic precipitates . Ring abscess. Acanthamoeba keratitis: A, Radial Kerato neuritis; B, Acanthamoeba pseudo dendrites; C, Ring infiltrate; D, Ring abscess

questions.text: The following MRI image shows a malignancy. What is the visual field defect observed in this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bitemporal hemianopia Above MRI shows tumor pituitary (Likely pituitary macroadenoma) compressing optic chiasma, which results in Bitemporal hemianopia.

Highyeild:

VISUAL FIELD DEFECTS Lesions of the visual pathways at the level of: 1. optic nerve; 2. proximal part of optic nerve; 3. central chiasma; 4. lateral chiasma (both sides); 5. optic tract; 6. geniculate body, 7. part of optic radiations in temporal lobe: 8. part of optic radiations in the parietal lobe; 9. optic radiations; 10. visual cortex sparing the macula: 11. visual cortex, only macula; 12. bilateral visual cortex only macula

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Complete blindness is seen in optic nerve damage. Option: B. Homonymous hemianopia is seen in lesions involving visual pathway posterior to optic chiasma. Option: C. Binasal hemianopia is seen in lesions affecting bilateral lateral chiasma.

questions.text: In a child the normal resolution visual acuity levels such as that of adults i.e. 6/6 is attained by which age?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

6 years From 9 months onwards formal tests of vision can be attempted, but it is not until 6 years of age that the normal resolution visual acuity levels such as that of adults i.e. 6/6, is attained.

Highyeild:

The new born's eye is short, generally hypermetropic and fovea is immature Very soon after birth the baby can 'fix' or look at a light help a few inches away momentarily. 1 month the fixation of light becomes more steady and the baby develops a preference for looking at a face or face like stimulus over any other object nearby 3 month-binocular vision and eye coordination are established and the eye will follow a torch helped in front of the face or person moving across the room. At 4 months the infant displays a recognition pattern similar to an adult if a face is presented upside down. 6 months of age ability to reach out, grasp and play with small objects and efforts to adjust position to see a toy develop. From 9 months onwards formal tests of vision can be attempted, but it is not until 6 years of age that the normal resolution visual acuity levels such as that of adults i.e. 6/6, 20120 are attained. The critical period for developing the fixation reflex in both unilateral and bilateral visual deprivation disorder is between 2 and 4 months of age. Any cataract dense enough to impair vision must be dealt with before this age and the earliest possible time is preferred.

questions.text: A 26-year-old teacher presents with a red nodule over her sclera, which resolves with medications but is recurrent. Identify the condition and what else will you look for in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Episcleritis; Rheumatoid arthritis Red nodule on sclera with history of recurrence suggestions diagnosis of nodular episcleritis. It is associated with Rheumatoid arthritis.

Highyeild:

EPISCLERITIS Episcleritis is benign, recurrent, inflammation of the episclera, involving the overlying Tenon's capsule but not the underlying sclera. It typically affects young adults, being twice as common in women than men. Episcleritis is characterised by redness, mild ocular discomfort described as gritty, burning or foreign body sensation. Simple episcleritis accounts for 75% of cases and is characterised by sectorial (occasionally diffuse) inflammation of episclera. The engorged episcleral vessels are large and run in radial direction beneath the conjunctiva. Nodular episcleritis is characterised by a pink or purple Flat nodule surrounded by injection, usually situated 2-3 mm away from the limbus . The nodule is firm, tender, can be moved separately from the sclera and the overlying conjunctiva also moves freely. Episcleritis: A, Diffuse; B, Nodular

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Pinguecula is a bilateral, usually stationary condition, preseming as yellowish white triangular patch near the limbus. Apex of the triangle is away from the cornea. It affects the nasal side first and then the temporal side. Pinguecula Option: C. Pterygium (L. Pterygion = a wing) is a vving-shaped fold of conjunctiva encroaching upon the cornea from either side within the interpalpebraJ fissure. Pterygium Option: D. Scleritis refers to an inflammation of the sclera proper. It is a comparatively serious disease which may cause visual impairment and even loss of the eye if treated inadequately. Patients complain of moderate to severe pain which is deep and boring in character and often wakes the patient early in the morning. Photophobia and Lacrimation may be mild to moderate.

questions.text: A patient who was watching a movie suddenly developed acute pain in the eye and diminution in vision. He was brought to the emergency department and on examination, a shallow anterior chamber was noted. What would be the appropriate management for this condition? IV-Intravenous e/d- Eyedrops
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IV Mannitol + pilocarpine e/d Above clinical scenario with mid dilated pupil as shown in the image , with shallow anterior chamber is suggestive of acute angle closure glaucoma. Appropriate management for this patient is intravenous mannitol and topical pilocarpine.

Highyeild:

Acute angle closure is a serious ocular emergency and needs to be managed aggressively as below: Immediate medical therapy to lower IOP Systemic hyperosmotic agents are required initially if IOP is more than 40 mm Hg. Intravenous mannitol. Systemic carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, e.g. acetazolamide Topical antiglaucoma drugs to be instilled immediately include: Beta-blocker, Alpha adrenergic agonists, e.g. brimonidine, Prostaglandin analogue, e.g. latanoprost Pilocarpine 2% QID should be started after 1 hour of the commencement of the treatment, i.e. when IOP is lowered, as at higher IOP sphincter is ischaemic and unresponsive to pilocarpine. Definitive therapy Laser peripheral iridotomy (LPI)- Laser peripheral iridotomy (with Nd:YAG laser or Argon Laser) should always be preferred over surgical PI. Prophylactic treatment in the normal fellow eye - Prophylactic laser iridotomy (preferably) or surgical peripheral iridectomy should be performed on the fellow asymptomatic eye (PACS) as early as possible as chances of acute attack are 50% in such eyes.

questions.text: Identify the defect shown in the image:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Herbert pits The above image shows tiny lesions at the limbus, indicating Herbert’s pits. This is seen in Trachoma.

Highyeild:

TRACHOMA Trachoma(previously known as Egyplian ophthalmia) is a chronic keratoconjunctivitis, primarily affecting the superficial epithelium of conjunctiva and cornea simultaneously. It is characterised by a mixed follicular and papillary response of conjunctival tissue, pannus formation and in late stages cicatrization giving rough appearance. Signs: Congestion of upper tarsal and forniceal conjunctiva. Conjunctival follicles- Follicles look like boiled sago-grains and are commonly seen on upper tarsal conjunctiva and fornix. Herbert follicles refer to typical follicles present in the limbal area. Histologically these are similar to conjunctival follicle. Trachomatous Herbert's pits Progressive pannus, i.e. infiltration of the cornea associated with vascularization is seen in the upper part . Conjunctiva/ scarring which may be irregular, star-shaped or linear. Linear scar present in the sulcus subtarsalis is called Arlt's line.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: B. Horner trantas spots are white , chalky , gelatinous nodules made of eosinophils and epithelial debris that appear at the limbus and are characteristic of limbal vernal keratoconjunctivitis. Option: C. In giant papillary conjunctivitis, gelatinous papillae initially appear as small, elevated nodules on the conjunctiva. Option: D. Pannus in Trachoma involves the infiltration of the cornea with new blood vessels developing in the upper part, lying between the epithelium and bowman’s membrane.

questions.text: Identify the visual field defect in the given image:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Homonymous hemianopia The visual field defect given in the above image is Right homonymous hemianopia.

Highyeild:

VISUAL FIELD DEFECTS Lesions of the visual pathways at the level of: 1. optic nerve; 2. proximal part of optic nerve; 3. central chiasma; 4. lateral chiasma (both sides); 5. optic tract; 6. geniculate body, 7. part of optic radiations in temporal lobe: 8. part of optic radiations in parietal lobe; 9. optic radiations; 10. visual cortex sparing the macula: 11. visual cortex, only macula; 12. bilateral visual cortex only macula
